Gets Premiere Date & Teaser|last=Petski|first=Denise|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=February 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/tv/girlboss-netflix-series-first-look-photo-exlusive/|title=FIRST LOOK! See the First Shot From Netflix’s Highly Anticipated Adaptation of #Girlboss|date=2017-01-05|newspaper=PEOPLE.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref> The show was cancelled after one season.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hollywoodlife.com/2017/06/24/girlboss-canceled-sophia-amoruso-throws-shade-netflix-series/|title='Girlboss' Canceled: Sophia Amoruso Throws Shade At Netflix For Botching Series|last=Rogers|first=Christopher|last2=Rogers|first2=Christopher|date=2017-06-25|website=Hollywood Life|access-date=2017-06-25}}</ref>
==Premise== The show is based on [[Sophia Amoruso]]'s [[autobiography]] ''#Girlboss'',<ref name="Fair"/> which tells the story of how Amoruso started the company [[Nasty Gal]] while working as a campus safety host for San Francisco's [[Academy of Art University]].
==Cast== ===Main=== *[[Britt Robertson]] as [[Sophia Amoruso|Sophia Marlowe]] *[[Ellie Reed (actress)|Ellie Reed]] as Annie, Sophia's best friend. *[[Johnny Simmons]] as Shane, Sophia's love-interest. *[[Alphonso McAuley]] as Dax, a bartender studying business and Annie's boyfriend.
===Recurring=== *[[Dean Norris]] as Jay Marlowe, Sophia's father *[[Norm Macdonald]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Norm Macdonald Jokes He's A 'Deeply Closeted Gay Guy'|url=http://www.ontopmag.com/article/23492/Norm_Macdonald_Jokes_Hes_A_Deeply_Closeted_Gay_Guy|website=ontopmag.com|accessdate=23 March 2017}}</ref> as Rick, Sophia's best and last boss. *[[RuPaul Charles]] as Lionel,<ref name="Trailer">{{cite web|last1=Nguyen|first1=Hanh|title='Girlboss' Trailer: A Nasty Gal Learns That Online Retail Can Be a Bitch in New Netflix Series|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/04/girlboss-trailer-netflix-nasty-gal-1201799990/|website=www.indiewire.com|accessdate=5 April 2017}}</ref> Sophia's neighbor *[[Jim Rash]]<ref name="Trailer"/> as Mobias, the owner of a consignment shop *[[Louise Fletcher]] as Rosie, a bitter old lady *[[Melanie Lynskey]] as Gail, the owner of Rememberences and a vintage clothing seller. *[[Macedo (musical group)|Macedo (Michelle and Melissa)]] as members of Shane's band.
==Production== In February 2016, it was announced that [[Netflix]] had ordered a series based on Amoruso's autobiography ''#Girlboss''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Netflix Orders Sophia Amoruso's '#Girlboss' to Series (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/netflixs-girlboss-series-sophia-amoruso-1201697580/|website=Variety|accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref> It was announced that the first season had gotten an order of 13 episodes.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=Britt Robertson To Topline 'Girlboss' Netflix Comedy Series|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/britt-robertson-star-girlboss-netflix-series-1201765008/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref> In June 2016, [[Britt Robertson]] joined the cast of the series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/britt-robertson-star-girlboss-netflix-series-1201765008/|title=Britt Robertson To Topline 'Girlboss' Netflix Comedy Series|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Nellie|last=Andreeva|date=June 2, 2016|accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref> That same month, [[Johnny Simmons]], [[Alphonso McAuley]] and [[Ellie Reed (actress)|Ellie Reed]] joined the cast.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title='Girlboss': Johnny Simmons Cast In Netflix Series|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/girlboss-johnny-simmons-cast-netflix-series-1201777258/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/vine-star-alphonso-mcauley-cast-girlboss-netflix-comedy-series-britt-robertson-1201773172/|title=Vine Star Alphonso McAuley Cast In ‘Girlboss’ Netflix Comedy Series|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=2016-06-15|newspaper=Deadline|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=Ellie Reed Cast In Netflix Comedy Series 'Girlboss', Signs With CAA|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/ellie-reed-cast-female-lead-girlboss-netflix-comedy-series-signs-caa-1201780878/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref> In July 2016, [[Dean Norris]] joined the cast in a recurring role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/07/dean-norris-cast-girlboss-netflix-comedy-series-britt-robertson-1201784387/|title=Dean Norris Joins 'Girlboss' Netflix Comedy Series|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Denise|last=Petski|date=July 8, 2016|accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref>
[[Principal photography]] took place in [[San Francisco]] and [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Girlboss|url=http://www.backstage.com/resources/detail/productionlisting/girlboss-85768/|website=backstage|accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref>
==Reception== Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the first season a 32% rating based on 25 reviews and an average rating of 5.94/10.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/girlboss/s01 | title=Girlboss | website=rottentomatoes.com | publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=October 1, 2016 }}</ref> [[Metacritic]] gives the series a score of 53 out of 100, based on 13 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/girlboss | title=GirlBoss - Season 1 Reviews | website=metacritic.com | publisher=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=October 1, 2016 }}</ref>
Some critics criticized the main character's unlikeability, but praised Robertson's portrayal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/reviews/girlboss-review-nasty-gal-sophia-amoruso-britt-robertson-1202028614/|title=TV Review: 'Girlboss' on Netflix|first=Sonia|last=Saraiya|date=April 17, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/girlboss-held-back-smudged-resume-253553|title=Girlboss held back by a smudged résumé|first=Esther|last=Zuckerman|publisher=|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2017/04/12/girlboss-netflix-review-britt-robertson-millennials/|title='Girlboss': Yet another show about an entitled millennial, blerg|first=Saba|last=Hamedy|website=Mashable|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
Critics were divided as to whether the show presented a feminist message. Jennifer Wright from ''New York Post'' called the show a "feminist fraud" because of Sophia's selfishness.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2017/04/22/girlboss-is-a-feminist-fraud/|title='Girlboss' is a feminist fraud|first=Jennifer|last=Wright|date=April 22, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref> However, Amy Otto from ''The Federalist'' praised it as a story of empowerment in the way Sophia creates her own brand based on her vision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thefederalist.com/2017/04/25/girlboss-epitomizes-capitalism-empowers-women/|title=Sorry, Feminists, 'Girlboss' Epitomizes How Capitalism Empowers Women|first=|last=Television|date=April 25, 2017|website=The Federalist|accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref> On 18 April 2018, Zimbio criticized the show saying it was "like the weird forgotten cousin of [[Degrassi: The Next Generation|Degrassi]]".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zimbio.com/Every+Netflix+Original+Show,+Ranked+From+Best+To+Worst/articles/Rq5yXxmv0iA/Girlboss+WORST|title='Girlboss' (WORST)|work=Zimbio|access-date=2018-05-10|language=en}}</ref>
==Episodes== {{Episode table |background=#F157E6 |overall= |title= |director= |writer= |airdate= |released=y |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = Sophia | DirectedBy = Christian Ditter | WrittenBy = [[Kay Cannon]] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = In 2006, 23-year-old Sophia Marlowe is fired from her job at a [[San Francisco]] shoe store and behind on her rent. When browsing a consignment store, she buys a vintage 1970s motorcycle jacket for nine dollars and sells it on [[eBay]] for $600. This gives her the idea to start her own vintage clothing business on eBay. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = The Hern | DirectedBy = Christian Ditter | WrittenBy = Kay Cannon | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Sophia has a crisis in confidence when her business hits a bump. She goes to an estate sale to try to find vintage clothing to sell. She discovers she has a [[hernia]], but has no health insurance. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = Thank You, San Francisco | DirectedBy = Christian Ditter | WrittenBy = Caroline Williams | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Desperate to come up with a name for her business, Sophia shows Shane around her beloved [[San Francisco]], counting on the city to give her inspiration. She and Shane have differing opinions on whether it is a date or not. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | Title = Ladyshopper99 | DirectedBy = [[Steven Tsuchida]] | WrittenBy = Sonny Lee | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Terrified of getting a bad review on eBay, Sophia goes to great lengths to make sure a vintage wedding dress is fixed and delivered to a high-strung bride in time for the wedding. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | Title = Top 8 | DirectedBy = Steven Tsuchida | WrittenBy = Eben Russell | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = After having a fight with Annie, Sophia reflects on their friendship, including their initial meeting at a [[San Francisco Giants]] game and a rocky trip to [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]]. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = Five Percent | DirectedBy = [[John Riggi]] | WrittenBy = Kay Cannon | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Shane leaves to go on tour. When she finally gets health insurance, Sophia ponders whether to quit her job at the [[Academy of Art University]] to focus solely on Nasty Gal. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | Title = Long-Ass Pants | DirectedBy = [[Amanda Brotchie]] | WrittenBy = [[Jake Fogelnest]] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Gail, the owner of a competing vintage clothing business in [[Reno, Nevada]], comes out to [[San Francisco]] to criticize the way Sophia runs her business. Sophia shows her a night on the town and the two end up unexpectedly bonding. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | Title = The Trip | DirectedBy = Amanda Brotchie | WrittenBy = Joanna Calo | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Sophia, Annie, and Dax take a road trip to [[Los Angeles]] to visit Shane, who is on tour there. The fun, romantic trip goes sour when Sophia and Shane end up fighting about their jobs. Annie and Dax go on a drug trip, prompting a confession from Dax. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | Title = Motherfuckin' Bar Graphs | DirectedBy = [[Jamie Babbit]] | WrittenBy = Jen Braeden | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Sophia seeks out a rental space for her business. When she needs a co-signer, she is forced to turn to her dad for help. Eager to prove to him that she is a responsible and capable business owner, she enlists Dax's help, but finds that her father does not totally trust her. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | Title = Vintage Fashion Forum | DirectedBy = Jamie Babbit | WrittenBy = Caroline Williams & Sonny Lee | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = When Annie asks Sophia for a job at Nasty Gal, she gets an unexpected answer. Sophia's competitors plot to take her down. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | Title = Garbage Person | DirectedBy = Jamie Babbit | WrittenBy = Kay Cannon & Eben Russell | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = When her business hits a major bump, Sophia takes a trip to visit someone from her past. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | Title = I Come Crashing | DirectedBy = Christian Ditter | WrittenBy = Kay Cannon | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = With the launch date for her website quickly approaching and much work to do, Sophia and Shane begin to grow distant from one another. Sophia stumbles upon a surprising discovery. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | Title = The Launch | DirectedBy = Christian Ditter | WrittenBy = Kay Cannon | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|4|21}} | ShortSummary = Sophia and Annie throw a party to celebrate the launch of the website, but Sophia is distracted by her problems with Shane. | LineColor =#F157E6 }} }}

{{For|the collectible card game|Hecatomb (card game)}} In [[ancient Greece]], a '''hecatomb''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|ɛ|k|ə|t|uː|m}} or {{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|ɛ|k|ə|t|oʊ|m}}; {{lang-grc|ἑκατόμβη}} ''hekatómbē'') was a sacrifice to the gods of 100 cattle (''hekaton'' = one hundred, ''bous'' = bull). In practice, as few as 12 could make up a hecatomb.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jones|first1=Peter|title=Homer's Odyssey : a companion to the English translation of Richmond Lattimore|date=1988|publisher=Bristol Classical Press|location=Bristol|isbn=1853990388|page=5|edition=[Repr.]}}</ref>
Although originally the sacrifice of a hundred oxen in the religious ceremonies of the Greeks and Romans; later "hecatomb" came to describe a large number of any kind of animals devoted for sacrifice. Figuratively, "hecatomb" is used to describe the sacrifice or destruction by fire, tempest, disease or the sword of any large number of persons or animals; and also of the wholesale destruction of inanimate objects, and even of mental and moral attributes.<ref>{{EB1911|inline=1 |wstitle=Hecatomb |volume=13 |page=194}}</ref>
==Ancient Greece== Hecatombs were offered to Greek gods [[Hera]], [[Athena]], and [[Apollo]], during special religious ceremonies.<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://dagr.univ-tlse2.fr/sdx/dagr/feuilleter.xsp?tome=3&partie=1&numPage=57&nomEntree=HEKATOMBAIA Le Dictionnaire des Antiquités Grecques et Romaines de Daremberg et Saglio (consultation de l'ensemble du corpus)]</ref> At the end of the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]], a hecatomb was also offered to [[Zeus]] at Olympia.
In the [[Iliad]] hecatombs are described formulaically. The following is one instance, from [[Samuel Butler (novelist)|Samuel Butler]]'s translation:
{{quote|[T]hey arranged the holy hecatomb all orderly round the altar of the god. They washed their hands and took up the barley-meal to sprinkle over the victims [cattle], while [the priest] lifted up his hands and prayed aloud on their behalf.
...
When they had done praying and sprinkling the barley-meal, they drew back the heads of the victims (Cattle) and killed and [[flaying|flayed]] them. They cut out the thigh-bones, wrapped them round in two layers of fat, set some pieces of raw meat on the top of them, and then [the priest] laid them on the wood fire and poured wine over them, while the young men stood near him with five-pronged spits in their hands. When the thigh-bones were burned and they had tasted the inward meats, they cut the rest up small, put the pieces upon the spits, roasted them till they were done, and drew them off: then, when they had finished their work and the feast was ready, they ate it, and every man had his full share, so that all were satisfied. As soon as they had had enough to eat and drink, pages filled the mixing-bowls with wine and water and handed it round, after giving every man his drink-offering.
Thus all day long the young men worshipped the god with song, hymning him and chaunting the joyous paean, and the god took pleasure in their voices[.]<ref>{{cite book |author=Homer |translator-last=Butler |translator-first=Samuel |translator-link=Samuel Butler (novelist) |year=1898 |chapter=[[s:The Iliad of Homer (Butler)/Book 1|Book 1]] (428–450)|title=[[s:The Iliad (Butler)|The Iliad]] |pages=12–13}} </ref> }}

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Hope Hicks |image = Hope Hicks November 2017.jpg |office = [[White House Director of Communications]] |president = [[Donald Trump]] |deputy = [[Mercedes Schlapp]] |term_start = September 12, 2017 |term_end = March 29, 2018
{{small|Acting: August 16, 2017 – September 12, 2017}} |predecessor = [[Anthony Scaramucci]] |successor = [[Bill Shine]] |office1 = 1st [[White House Director of Strategic Communications]] |leader1 = [[Sean Spicer]]
[[Michael Dubke]]
[[Sean Spicer]] {{small|(Acting)}}
[[Anthony Scaramucci]] |president1 = [[Donald Trump]] |term_start1 = January 20, 2017 |term_end1 = September 12, 2017 |predecessor1 = Position established |successor1 = [[Mercedes Schlapp]] |birth_name = Hope Charlotte Hicks |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|10|21}} |birth_place = [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |education = [[Southern Methodist University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) }} '''Hope Charlotte Hicks''' (born October 21, 1988) is an American [[public relations]] consultant who served as the [[White House Communications Director]] for [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Donald Trump]] from August 2017 until March 29, 2018.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/12/us/politics/trump-hope-hicks-white-house-communications-director.html |title=Hope Hicks Is Formally Named White House Communications Director |last=Haberman |first=Maggie |date=September 12, 2017 |work=The New York Times|access-date=September 14, 2017 |issn=0362-4331 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170914081914/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/12/us/politics/trump-hope-hicks-white-house-communications-director.html |archivedate=September 14, 2017 }}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-bids-farewell-close-aide-hope-hicks/story?id=54098040|title=Trump bids farewell to close aide Hope Hicks|first=A. B. C.|last=News|date=March 29, 2018|website=ABC News|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} From January to September 2017, she was [[White House Director of Strategic Communications]], a role created for her. She previously was a teenage model but then became [[press secretary]] and early communications director for Trump's [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]], as well as the national press secretary for his [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|presidential transition team]],{{cite web |url=http://www.marieclaire.com/politics/news/a20905/donald-trump-communications-director-hope-hicks/ |title=Meet Donald Trump's 27-Year-Old Communications Director, Hope Hicks |last1=Nelson |first1=Rebecca |website=Marie Clare |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170128014010/http://www.marieclaire.com/politics/news/a20905/donald-trump-communications-director-hope-hicks/ |archivedate=January 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |accessdate=January 22, 2017 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/donald-trump-administration/2016/12/donald-trump-hunting-conservation-trip-232863 |title=Trump transition seeks distance from conservation fundraiser |last1=Nussbaum |first1=Matthew |accessdate=December 21, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221005520/http://www.politico.com/blogs/donald-trump-administration/2016/12/donald-trump-hunting-conservation-trip-232863 |archivedate=December 21, 2016 |deadurl=no |publisher=Politico }} and before that was an employee of [[The Trump Organization]]. She was Trump's longest-serving political aide at the time of her resignation.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/26/style/hope-hicks-donald-trump.html |title=The Woman Who 'Totally Understands' Donald Trump |last1=Grynbaum |first1=Michael |date=June 26, 2016 |website=The New York Times |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106190116/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/26/style/hope-hicks-donald-trump.html |archivedate=January 6, 2017 |deadurl=no |accessdate=January 21, 2017 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/politics/news/a9056/hope-hicks-facts/ |title=15 Things You Should Know About Hope Hicks, Donald Trump's Director of Strategic Communications |last1=Dangremond |first1=Sam |website=Town&Country |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230161932/http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/politics/news/a9056/hope-hicks-facts/ |archivedate=December 30, 2016 |deadurl=no }} On February 27, 2018, Hicks testified to a Congressional committee that she had told "white lies" on Trump's behalf.{{cite web |accessdate=March 11, 2018 |title=Hope Hicks, the White House aide snared by white lies |url=https://www.ft.com/content/c8af71a2-1d49-11e8-aaca-4574d7dabfb6 |website=Financial Times}}{{cite news |first1=Nicholas |last1=Fandos |accessdate=March 11, 2018 |title=Hope Hicks Acknowledges She Sometimes Tells White Lies for Trump |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/27/us/politics/hope-hicks-house-intelligence-committee-testimony.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 27, 2018 |issn=0362-4331 |via=NYTimes.com}}{{cite web |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/28/politics/hope-hicks-testimony/index.html |title=What Hope Hicks meant about white lies |first1=Manu |last1=Raju |first2=Jeremy |last2=Herb |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=March 1, 2018|access-date=March 1, 2018}} The next day, Hicks announced her intention to resign as White House Communications Director.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/28/us/politics/hope-hicks-resign-communications-director.html |title=Hope Hicks to Leave Post as White House Communications Director |last=Haberman |first=Maggie |date=February 28, 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=March 1, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/white-house-aide-hope-hicks-resign-sources/story |title=White House communications director Hope Hicks to resign |website=ABC News}} She left the White House a month later.{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/380830-trump-bids-farewell-to-hope-hicks |title=Trump bids farewell to Hope Hicks|author=Tristan Lejeune|date=March 29, 2018|work=The Hill|accessdate=March 30, 2018}} In 2019, she will begin working for [[Fox News|Fox]] as [[chief communications officer]] and executive vice president.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/08/media/hope-hicks-joins-fox/index.html|title=Former Trump aide Hope Hicks joins Fox as head of PR|last=Selter|first=Brian|publisher=CNN|date=October 8, 2018|accessdate=October 26, 2018}} ==Early life== Hicks is the daughter of Caye Ann (Cavender) Hicks and Paul Burton Hicks III.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/16/style/paul-hicks-weds-caye-a-cavender.html |title=Paul Hicks Weds Caye A. Cavender |date=May 16, 1982 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170128003106/http://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/16/style/paul-hicks-weds-caye-a-cavender.html |archivedate=January 28, 2017 }} She grew up in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]]. Her father was Regional CEO, Americas[https://www.linkedin.com/in/paul-hicks-a507837/ Paul Hicks's LinkedIn], [[LinkedIn]], Retrieved August 3, 2017. of [[Ogilvy & Mather|Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide]], and executive vice president of communications for the [[National Football League]] from 2010 to 2015, before becoming managing director of [[the Glover Park Group]].{{cite web |last1=Sebastian |first1=Michael |last2=Friedman |first2=Megan |url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/news/a56404/who-is-hope-hicks-trump-press-secretary/ |title=16 Things to Know About Hope Hicks, President Trump's Communications Director |publisher=''Cosmopolitan'' |date=February 28, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228234826/https://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/news/a56404/who-is-hope-hicks-trump-press-secretary/ |archivedate=February 28, 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://blog.smu.edu/smumagazine/2016/06/on-the-campaign-trail-with-smu-alum-hope-hicks-10-donald-trumps-communications-director/ |title=On The Campaign Trail With SMU Alum Hope Hicks '10, Donald Trump's Communications Director |publisher=''Southern Methodist University Magazine'' |date=June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160623070119/http://blog.smu.edu/smumagazine/2016/06/on-the-campaign-trail-with-smu-alum-hope-hicks-10-donald-trumps-communications-director/ |archivedate=June 23, 2016}}{{cite web |last1=Vigdor |first1=Neil |url=http://www.ctpost.com/printpromotion/article/Greenwich-natives-help-Trump-Bush-and-Obama-hone-6425215.php |title=Greenwich natives help Trump, Bush and Obama hone their message |publisher=''Connecticut Post'' |date=August 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180210061936/https://www.ctpost.com/printpromotion/article/Greenwich-natives-help-Trump-Bush-and-Obama-hone-6425215.php |archivedate=February 10, 2018}} Her family had a history in politics: her mother was an aide to [[Ed Jones (U.S. politician)|Ed Jones]], a Democratic congressman from Tennessee; her maternal grandfather, G. W. F. "Dutch" Cavender, worked in the U.S. Department of Agriculture during two different administrations; and her maternal grandmother, Marilee Cavender, worked at the U.S. Department of Transportation.{{Cite news |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/03/what-hope-hicks-learned-in-washington.html |title=What Hope Hicks Learned in Washington |last=Nuzzi |first=Olivia |date=March 18, 2018 |work=New York Magazine|access-date=March 19, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |language=en}} Hicks was a teenage model, appearing in ''Greenwich'' magazine in 2002. She then posed for a [[Ralph Lauren Corporation|Ralph Lauren]] campaign with her older sister Mary Grace, and was the face of the ''Hourglass Adventures'' novels about a time-traveling 10-year-old. She was the cover model for ''[[The It Girl (novel)|The It Girl]]'' (2005), the first novel in the series by [[Cecily von Ziegesar]].{{cite web |last=Koman |first=Tess |date=June 21, 2016 |title=Here's Why Donald Trump's 27-Year-Old Press Secretary Looks So Familiar |work=Cosmopolitan |url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/news/a60212/hope-hicks-gossip-girl-series-cover/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160622130106/http://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/news/a60212/hope-hicks-gossip-girl-series-cover/ |archivedate=June 22, 2016 |deadurl=no}} Hicks attended [[Greenwich High School]], where she was co-captain of the [[lacrosse]] team, and graduated in 2006.{{cite news |last=Viser |first=Matt |date=November 10, 2016 |title=Hope Hicks Is Everything Her Boss Donald Trump Is Not |url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/politics/a7274/hope-hicks-donald-trump/ |newspaper=[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]] |location=New York City |access-date=November 23, 2016 |quote=At age 11 she and her older sister were hired to model for Ralph Lauren. Soon she was in the pages of national magazines and had a cameo on the soap opera Guiding Light. She became the face of the Hourglass Adventures, a series of novels for preteen girls featuring a 10-year-old who travels back in time.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ctpost.com/news/article/Hope-change-Greenwich-prodigy-breakout-star-of-10609608.php |title=Hope & change: The breakout star of Trump's campaign |publisher=''Connecticut Post'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629232707/http://www.ctpost.com/news/article/Hope-change-Greenwich-prodigy-breakout-star-of-10609608.php |archivedate=June 29, 2017}} She then attended [[Southern Methodist University]], where she majored in English and played on a club lacrosse program she helped start. She graduated in 2010.{{cite web |url=http://laxmagazine.prestosports.com/mag/images/110416_a_public_relation |title=From the Mag: A Public Relation |first1=Matt |last1=Hamilton |publisher=''Lacrosse Magazine'' |date=November 4, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816150613/http://laxmagazine.prestosports.com/mag/images/110416_a_public_relation |archivedate=August 16, 2017}} ==Career== Hicks started in [[public relations]] with the New York City firm Zeno Group. She began working for public relations firm [[Matthew Hiltzik|Hiltzik Strategies]] in 2012, after meeting the firm's founder at an NFL [[Super Bowl]] event, and worked there for [[Donald Trump]]'s daughter [[Ivanka Trump]], on her fashion line, and then on other Trump ventures.{{cite web |last=Nuzzi |first=Olivia |date=June 20, 2016 |url=https://www.gq.com/story/hope-hicks-mystifying-triumph-donald-trump |title=The Mystifying Triumph of Hope Hicks, Donald Trump's Right-Hand Woman |work=[[GQ]] |accessdate=June 20, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620115755/http://www.gq.com/story/hope-hicks-mystifying-triumph-donald-trump |archivedate=June 20, 2016 }}{{cite web |last1=Diamond |first1=Jeremy |date=November 27, 2017 |title=Hope Hicks: A witness to Trump's rise |work=CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/26/politics/hope-hicks-donald-trump-white-house/index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171127021148/http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/26/politics/hope-hicks-donald-trump-white-house/index.html |archivedate=November 27, 2017 |deadurl=no }} In August 2014, Hicks joined [[The Trump Organization]] full-time.{{cite web |last=Viebeck |first=Elise |date=July 27, 2015 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2015/07/27/hope-hicks-flies-quietly-in-the-eye-of-the-trump-storm/ |title=Hope Hicks flies quietly in the eye of the Trump storm |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=June 20, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160802144030/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2015/07/27/hope-hicks-flies-quietly-in-the-eye-of-the-trump-storm/ |archivedate=August 2, 2016 }} She worked for Ivanka Trump inside [[Trump Tower]], helping expand her fashion label (the Ivanka Trump Collection) and modeling for her online store.[http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/celebrity/hope-hicks-and-kellyanne-conway--the-women-of-donald-trumps-inner-circle-20161114-gsop4c.html "Hope Hicks and Kellyanne Conway – the women of Donald Trump's inner circle"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227002053/http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/celebrity/hope-hicks-and-kellyanne-conway--the-women-of-donald-trumps-inner-circle-20161114-gsop4c.html |date=February 27, 2017 }}, ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' In October 2014, she began working directly for Donald Trump.{{Cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/11/16/hope-hicks-mueller-russia-probe-trump-244967 |title=Hope Hicks may hold the keys to Mueller's Russia puzzle |last=Samuelshohn |first=Darren |date=November 16, 2017 |work=POLITICO|access-date=November 26, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171126050700/https://www.politico.com/story/2017/11/16/hope-hicks-mueller-russia-probe-trump-244967|archive-date=November 26, 2017|dead-url=no }} In January 2015, Donald Trump chose Hicks, who was 26 years old at the time, for the role of [[press secretary]] for his potential presidential campaign.{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/04/inside-the-donald-trump-presidential-campaign.html |title=Operation Trump: Inside the Most Unorthodox Campaign in Political History |last=Sherman |first=Gabriel |authorlink=Gabriel Sherman |date=April 3, 2016 |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |accessdate=June 20, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160622091418/http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/04/inside-the-donald-trump-presidential-campaign.html |archivedate=June 22, 2016 }}{{cite web |last=Tucker |first=Reed |date=September 25, 2015 |url=https://nypost.com/2015/09/25/meet-trumps-26-year-old-mystery-woman/ |title=Meet Trump's 26-year-old mystery woman |work=[[New York Post]] |accessdate=June 20, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625063355/http://nypost.com/2015/09/25/meet-trumps-26-year-old-mystery-woman/ |archivedate=June 25, 2016 }} Trump summoned her to his office and, as she tells it, "Mr. Trump looked at me and said, 'I'm thinking about running for president, and you're going to be my press secretary.{{'"}} Until that time, she had never worked in politics or volunteered on a campaign. After Trump's first primary victories, Hicks was asked to choose between staying with the Trump Organization or working on the campaign full-time. She initially decided to leave the campaign, but Trump convinced her to remain and she stayed on as press secretary. During the campaign, she played the role of gatekeeper to press members who wanted to speak with Trump, handling over 250 requests a day, and deciding which reporters would be allowed to speak with him. Hicks also took dictation from Trump for his [[Twitter|tweets]], and then sent the text to another person in the Trump organization who sent the tweets from Trump's official account.[https://www.yahoo.com/celebrity/10-things-know-hope-hicks-152314456.html "14 Things to Know About Hope Hicks, Donald Trump's 27-Year-Old Former Model Press Secretary",] [[Yahoo.com]] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604133512/https://www.yahoo.com/celebrity/10-things-know-hope-hicks-152314456.html |date=June 4, 2017 }} When in New York City, she would spend most of her day in Trump's office, handling inquiries from the press and taking dictation from him to tweet. On December 22, 2016, it was announced that Hicks would become part of the Trump Administration, in the newly created position of the [[White House Director of Strategic Communications]]. In January 2017, Hicks was included on the [[Forbes 30 Under 30|''Forbes'' 30 Under 30]] list, having "served as a one-woman press team for Trump's historic presidential campaign".{{cite web |title=Forbes 30 Under 30 |url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/fjle45eeelm/hope-hicks-28/ |website=Forbes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106030349/http://www.forbes.com/pictures/fjle45eeelm/hope-hicks-28/ |archivedate=January 6, 2017 }} On August 16, 2017, she was made the interim [[White House Communications Director]] (the last Director having been [[Anthony Scaramucci]]). ''Politico'' labelled her the "Untouchable Hope Hicks", as she was considered one of the few White House officials whose job was safe, and one of only two White House communications officials Scaramucci had announced were definitely staying when he was first hired.{{cite web |url=http://heavy.com/news/2017/08/hope-hicks-donald-trump-ivanka-melania-relationship-photos-communications-director-married-experience/ |title=Hope Hicks & Donald Trump: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know |publisher=Heavy |date=August 16, 2017 |first=Jessica |last=McBride |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816160807/http://heavy.com/news/2017/08/hope-hicks-donald-trump-ivanka-melania-relationship-photos-communications-director-married-experience/ |archivedate=August 16, 2017 }} She was appointed permanent White House Communications Director on September 12, 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/hope-hicks-named-white-house-communications-director-after-assuming-role-on-interim-basis-1505231198 |title=Hope Hicks Named Permanent White House Communications Director |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=September 12, 2017 |first=Rebecca |last=Ballhaus |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912163250/https://www.wsj.com/articles/hope-hicks-named-white-house-communications-director-after-assuming-role-on-interim-basis-1505231198 |archivedate=September 12, 2017 }} On February 27, 2018, Hicks gave nine hours of closed-door testimony to the House Intelligence Committee. She acknowledged that she sometimes had to tell "white lies" in her work as communications director, but refused to answer any questions about her tenure in the White House.{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/26/politics/hope-hicks-house-intelligence-committee/index.html |title=Hicks acknowledges white lies, but won't talk White House in testimony |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |date=February 28, 2018 |work=CNN |accessdate=February 28, 2018}} The next day the White House confirmed to ''[[The New York Times]]'' that Hicks planned to resign.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/28/us/politics/hope-hicks-resign-communications-director.html |title=Hope Hicks to Resign as White House Communications Director |last=Haberman |first=Maggie |date=February 28, 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=February 28, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} According to "multiple sources", she had been planning to resign for months, and her announcement was unrelated to the events of the preceding 24 hours.{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hope-hicks-trump-aide-is-resigning-2018-2 |title=Hope Hicks, one of Trump's closest confidants and longest-tenured aide, is resigning |last=Smith |first=Allan |date=February 28, 2018 |work=Business Insider |accessdate=March 1, 2018}} She officially resigned on March 29, 2018.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/29/us/politics/hope-hicks-white-house.html |title=Hope Hicks is Gone, and It's Not Clear Who Can Replace Her |last=Rogers |first=Katie |date=March 29, 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=March 30, 2018 |last2=Haberman |first2=Maggie |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} ==Personal life== Hicks and her sister lived in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], but she split her time between an apartment there and an apartment in Manhattan. When Trump was elected, she moved to Washington, D.C."[https://www.yahoo.com/news/hope-hicks-responsible-important-line-201814586.html Hope Hicks Was Responsible for an Important Line in the President's Speech] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170728145239/https://www.yahoo.com/news/hope-hicks-responsible-important-line-201814586.html |date=July 28, 2017 }}". Yahoo. Hicks allegedly dated Trump's campaign manager [[Corey Lewandowski]] while he was still married to Alison Hardy.{{cite news |first1=Mary |last1=Jordan |first2=Josh |last2=Dawsey |accessdate=March 11, 2018 |title=Hope Hicks: The quiet one in Trump's White House suddenly feels the glare |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/hope-hicks-the-quiet-one-in-trumps-white-house-suddenly-feels-the-glare/2018/02/09/738f0e74-0dba-11e8-8b0d-891602206fb7_story.html |newspaper=Washington Post |date=February 10, 2018 |issn=0190-8286 |via=www.washingtonpost.com}}{{cite news |accessdate=March 11, 2018 |title=Inside Hope Hicks' Troubled Romances with Ousted Top Trump Aides Rob Porter and Corey Lewandowski |url=http://people.com/politics/hope-hicks-dating-rob-porter-corey-lewandowski/ |newspaper=PEOPLE.com}}{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Kate |title=The Trump White House has been plagued by rumors of illicit romances — and now Hope Hicks is at the center |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hope-hicks-boyfriend-and-white-house-romances-2018-2/#hicks-and-corey-lewandowski-a-former-trump-campaign-manager-2 |accessdate=February 9, 2018 |work=Business Insider |date=February 8, 2018 |language=en |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208235423/http://www.businessinsider.com/hope-hicks-boyfriend-and-white-house-romances-2018-2#hicks-and-corey-lewandowski-a-former-trump-campaign-manager-2 |archivedate=February 8, 2018 }} She later began dating former White House [[White House Office of the Staff Secretary|Staff Secretary]] [[Rob Porter]], while he was caught up in a scandal for allegedly beating his two ex-wives.{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/rob-porter-hope-hicks-boyfriend-white-house-aide-resigning-amid-abuse-allegations/ |title=White House aide Rob Porter resigning amid abuse allegations |publisher=CBS News |date=February 8, 2018 |accessdate=February 8, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208000559/https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/rob-porter-hope-hicks-boyfriend-white-house-aide-resigning-amid-abuse-allegations/ |archivedate=February 8, 2018 }}{{cite news |accessdate=March 11, 2018 |title=Trump is reportedly blaming Hope Hicks in the Porter scandal |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/2/9/16995848/trump-hope-hicks-rob-porter-scandal |newspaper=Vox}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Ballotpedia|Hope_Hicks}} * {{C-SPAN|Hope Hicks}} * ''[https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/politics/100000005594976/hope-hicks-seen-but-not-heard.html Hope Hicks: Seen but not heard.]'' ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'', Cirillo, Chris. (December 9, 2017) {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Anthony Scaramucci]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[White House Communications Director|White House Director of Communications]]|years=2017–2018}} {{s-aft|after=[[Bill Shine]]}} {{s-end|}} {{WHCD}} {{Trump Executive Office}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hicks, Hope}} [[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:20th-century American women]] [[Category:21st-century American women]] [[Category:American press secretaries]] [[Category:American public relations people]] [[Category:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]] [[Category:Executive Office of the President of the United States]] [[Category:Female models from Connecticut]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:People associated with the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:People from Greenwich, Connecticut]] [[Category:Southern Methodist University alumni]] [[Category:Trump administration personnel]] [[Category:White House Communications Directors]] [[Category:Women in New York (state) politics]] [[Category:Fox Broadcasting Company executives]]

page.title: How to Be an American Housewife

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{unreliable sources|date=June 2012}} {{notability|Books|date=June 2012}} }} {{Infobox book | name = How To Be an American Housewife | image = How to Be an American Housewife.jpg | image_size = | caption = | alt = | author = [[Margaret Dilloway]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | subject = | genre = [[Chick lit]] [[Fiction]] | publisher = [[Penguin Publishing]] | publisher2 = | pub_date = {{Start date|2010}} | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = 978-0399156373 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | preceded_by_quotation_marks = | followed_by = | followed_by_quotation_marks = | wikisource = }} '''''How To Be An American Housewife''''' is a 2010 [[novel]] by [[Margaret Dilloway]]. It is based on the experiences of Dilloway's mother, who was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[war bride]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Newman |first=Judith |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20414634,00.html |title=Picks and Pans Main: Books |publisher=People.com |date=2010-08-23 |accessdate=2012-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Beth Carpenter, The Country Bookshop, Southern Pines, NC |url=http://www.indiebound.org/book/9780425241295 |title=How to Be an American Housewife |publisher=IndieBound |date=2011-08-02 |accessdate=2012-05-31}}</ref>
==Synopsis== The [[book]] tells the story of Shoko Morgan, a [[mother]] of two and wife to [[American people|American]] [[G.I. (military)|GI]] Charlie. Shoko decided to contact her brother Taro, whom she last saw when she married Charlie at the end of [[World War II]]. However, she is too ill to return her country. Shoko asked her daughter Sue and granddaughter to go to Japan to find her uncle to discover her mother's life secret.
==Characters== *'''Shoko Morgan''' - A Japanese Woman who married American GI, with whom she had 2 children *'''Suiko (Sue) Morgan''' - Shoko's and Charlie's daughter and brother to Mike and niece to Taro *'''Charlie Morgan''' - Shoko's husband and Mike's and Sue's father is an [[Irish-American]] GI who is kindhearted yet shy *'''Mike Morgan''' - Shoko's and Charlie's son and older brother of Sue *'''Taro''' - Shoko's younger brother and uncle to Sue and Mike, who hates Americans, retired from being a school principal *'''Mille Morgan''' - Charlie's mother, who become Shoko's mother in law and grandmother to Mike and Sue *'''Nanny''' - a [[babysitter]] whom Shoko disliked as a child *'''Craig''' - Sue's ex-husband and Helena's father, who married her at age of 20 *'''Suki''' - Taro's and Shoko's sister. *'''Ronin''' - an Eta whom Shoko fell in love with, born to an English father and Japanese mother. He and Shoko were lovers. He was killed by Testuo *'''Testuo''' - Taro's childhood friend, who was [[engaged]] to Shoko until he [[infidelity|cheated]] on her with her friend Yuki. *'''Toyoko''' - Japanese wife of black [[soldier]] *'''Jim''' - Toyoko's husband *'''Kyle Leonard''' - An American general who met Shoko *'''Lorraine'''- A neighbor of Charlie and Shoko *'''Dr Cunningham''' - Shoko's doctor *'''Helena''' - Sue's and Craig's 13-year-old daughter *'''Dr Su''' : Shoko's doctor is a [[Chinese-American]] *'''Toshiro''' : A Japanese traveler who met Sue and Helena *'''Yasuo Takana''' - Suki's son is a teacher at Ukei High School who met his cousin Sue *'''Hiroshi''' - Yasuo's [[paramour|lover]] *'''Sumiko''' - Taro's granddaughter, who met Sue and Helena *'''Taro-chan'''- Sumiko's four-year-old son, who shared his name with his great-grandfather
==Awards== The book was a John Gardner [[Fiction]] Award Finalist in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE BINGHAMTON UNIVERSITY JOHN GARDNER FICTION BOOK AWARD|url=http://www2.binghamton.edu/english/creative-writing/binghamton-center-for-writers/binghamton-book-awards/gardner-past-award-winners.html|work=Binghamton University|publisher=Binghamton Center for Writers|accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/7504179-how-to-be-an-american-housewife Goodreads] * http://www.readinggroupguides.com/guides_h/how_to_be_an_american_housewife1.asp

revision.comment: /* Further reading */ placed Shapiro and Varian (1998) in a cite template
revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} '''Information good''' in [[economics]] and [[law]] is a type [[commodity]] whose market value is derived from [[information]] it contains. Examples include [[Compact Disc|CD]]s containing pieces of music, [[DVD]]s containing movie content, and books containing short stories. Information goods are in contrast to material goods such as clothes, food, and cars. These can exist in either [[Digitizing|digitized form]] or [[Analog recording|analog format]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://people.ischool.berkeley.edu/~hal/Papers/japan/|title=Markets for Information Goods|website=people.ischool.berkeley.edu|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref>
In information goods, the valuable part is a pattern in which the material is arranged including the arrangement of ink on paper or a series of information on a compact disc. Those patterns might be either directly consumed through reading, viewing, or may be used to operate other devices such as a cassette player or a computer. The device, in turn, may produce some consumable pattern of information (such as visual, sound, or text).
== Economic theory == In [[economics]], information plays a double role. On one side, [[perfect information]] is a key requirement of the [[efficient-market hypothesis]]. Here, information is understood to be instantly available for everybody at no cost and fully complete. However, actual markets often depend on information as a commodity, hence information goods. Here, information is understood to be potentially restricted in terms of access, cost, availability, and completeness.
Economic theory faces the problem of constantly dealing with two contradictory concepts of information at the same time. If efficiency is the dominant aspect of analyses, it is likely that [[commodification]] is considered to be harmful. If incentive for creation is the dominant aspect of analyses, the protection of the creator is then likely to be dominant.<ref>Boyle, James. Shamans, Software, and Spleens: Law and the Construction of the Information Society. Cambridge: Harvard UP, 1996</ref>
==Market failure== A consumer may face [[uncertainty]] and not be able to assess accurately and reliably the utility of some information goods, such as novels, movies, and newspapers, before consumption of the goods. This is a peculiar property of information goods whereby the process of evaluating utility may require the very process of consumption. This uncertainty is a type of [[market failure]] known as the [[The Market for Lemons|lemon problem]] and is not unique to information goods.
Information goods may interact on the basis of [[artificial scarcity]]. Some information goods can be reproduced and distributed relatively inexpensively. An example would be copying recorded music from radio, cassette player, or CD player to a tape or computer hard disc.
Information goods are also not consumed by the act of copying. On this basis, some argue that information should be provided without cost and limitations to copying.
As digital technologies and digital electronic networks in some countries became very popular, it was very easy to reproduce and widely distribute some information goods. However, due to the difficulty of controlling the copying and distributing activities of people using such technologies, it is often harder for the producer of such goods to prevent illegal distribution of proprietary works. This operates on the principle of economic [[excludability]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Further reading ==
* {{cite book | last1 = Shapiro | first1 = Carl | last2 = Varian | first2 = Hal R | title = Information rules: a strategic guide to the network economy | date = November 1998 | publisher = Harvard Business School Press | location = Brighton, Massachusetts, USA | asin = 087584863X | isbn = 978-0875848631 }} Hardback.
==See also==
* [[Intellectual property]] * [[Copyright]] * [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] * [[File sharing]] * [[Information asymmetry]]
{{Goodtypes}} {{Portal bar|Business and economics}}

{{SCCInfoBox |case-name=Janzen v Platy Enterprises Ltd |full-case-name=Dianna Janzen and Tracy Govereau v Platy Enterprises Limited, and Platy Enterprises Limited, carrying on business under the firm name and style of Pharos Restaurant, and Tommy Grammas |heard-date=June 15, 1988 |decided-date=May 4, 1989 |citations=[1989] 1 S.C.R. 1252 |docket=20241 |history= |ruling=Janzen and Govereau appeal allowed. |ratio= |SCC=1988-1988 |Unanimous=Dickson C.J. |NotParticipating=Le Dain and Sopinka J. |LawsApplied=''[[Robichaud v Canada (Treasury Board)]]'', [1987] 2 S.C.R. 84, ''[[Brooks v Canada Safeway Ltd]]'', [1989] 1 S.C.R. }}'''''Janzen v Platy Enterprises Ltd''''' [1989] 1 S.C.R. 1252 is a leading [[Supreme Court of Canada]] decision on discrimination. The Court found that sexual harassment was as a form of discrimination based on sex and so was prohibited by the ''Manitoba Human Rights Act''.
==Background== During the fall of 1982, Dianna Janzen and Tracy Govereau were both employed as waitresses at Pharos restaurant in [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]]. Tommy Grammas, a cook at the restaurant, began making sexual advances to Janzen. She repeatedly made it clear that the advances were not welcome, nonetheless they continued. When Janzen approached Eleftherois Anastasiadis, the manager of the restaurant, he said, "if it's about Tommy, I can't do anything about it." Eventually, the advances were replaced with uncooperative and threatening behaviour. When Anastasiadis was approached about it he refused to act on it and instead fired the women.
The women sued Platy Enterprises Ltd., the owner of Phraos restaurant, as well as Tommy, under section 6(1) of the ''[[Manitoba Human Rights Act]]'', for violating their right to equal opportunity by firing them because of their sex.
The Manitoba Human Rights Tribunal held that the women had been subject to sexual harassment on the basis of sex and so the restaurant owners were in violation of section 6(1) of the Act. The Court of Queen's Bench upheld the decision.
The [[Manitoba Court of Appeal]] overturned the Court of Queen's Bench. The court found that sexual harassment was not considered discrimination on the basis of sex and that the employer could not be held vicariously liable of the conduct of the employee.
==Ruling of the Court== Chief Justice Dickson, writing for a unanimous Court, held that the restaurant's conduct did constitute discrimination on the basis of sex. Dickson rejected the Court of Appeal's ruling that the harassment was not based on sex because not all female employees were targeted. He stated that discrimination on the basis of sex is where there is a "practice or attitude which had the effect of limiting the conditions of employment of, or the employment opportunities available to, employees on the basis of a characteristic related to gender."
==See also== * [[List of Supreme Court of Canada cases (Dickson Court)]]
==External links== * {{lexum-scc2|1989|1|1252|97}}

{{Infobox Governor |image = Joe Kernan.jpg |order=48th |office= Governor of Indiana |term_start=September 13, 2003 |term_end=January 10, 2005 |lieutenant= [[Kathy Davis]] |predecessor= [[Frank O'Bannon]] |successor=[[Mitch Daniels]] |caption= |order2= |office2= 47th [[Lieutenant Governor of Indiana]] |term_start2= January 13, 1997 |term_end2= September 13, 2003
[[Acting governor|Acting Governor]]: Sept. 10, 2003 – Sept. 13, 2003 |governor2=Frank O'Bannon |predecessor2=[[Frank O'Bannon]] |successor2=[[Kathy Davis]] |office3= 30th Mayor of [[South Bend, Indiana|South Bend]] |term_start3= January 3, 1988 |term_end3= January 3, 1997 |predecessor3=Roger Parent{{cite web|url=http://historymuseumsb.org/list-of-south-bend-mayors/|title=List of South Bend Mayors|publisher=}} |successor3=[[Steve Luecke]] |birth_name=Joseph Eugene Kernan |birth_date= {{Birth date and age |1946|04|08}} |birth_place= [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. |death_date= |death_place= |spouse= [[Maggie Kernan]] |profession= [[Businessman]] |alma_mater = [[University of Notre Dame]] |party= [[United States Democratic Party|Democrat]] |branch=[[United States Navy]] |serviceyears= 1969–1974 (active duty)
1974–1982 (naval reserve) |battles=[[Vietnam War]], [[Cold War]] |residence=[[South Bend, Indiana]] |footnotes= }} '''Joseph Eugene Kernan''' (born April 8, 1946) is an American businessman and former politician who served as the [[List of Governors of Indiana|48th Governor of Indiana]] from 2003 to 2005. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], Kernan previously served as Mayor of [[South Bend, Indiana]], and then as the [[Lieutenant Governor of Indiana|47th Lieutenant Governor of Indiana]] from 1997 to 2003. He became governor on September 13, 2003, upon the death of Governor [[Frank O'Bannon]]. He lost an election to serve a full term as governor to former [[Office of Management and Budget]] director [[Mitch Daniels]] on November 2, 2004. Kernan returned to South Bend and retired from politics. ==Early life and education== Joe Kernan was born in [[Chicago, Illinois]] in 1946. He graduated from [[St. Joseph's High School (South Bend, Indiana)|St. Joseph's High School]] in [[South Bend, Indiana]]. He graduated in 1968 with a degree in [[Government]] from the [[University of Notre Dame]], where he was a resident of [[Stanford Hall (University of Notre Dame)|Stanford Hall]]. Kernan played baseball at Notre Dame in 1967 and 1968.{{cite web|url=http://www.und.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/030113aaa.html|title=USA Baseball-Irish Classic Debuts Friday|publisher=}} ==Military service== Kernan entered the [[United States Navy]] in 1969 and served as a [[Naval Flight Officer]] aboard the carrier [[USS Kitty Hawk (CV-63)|USS ''Kitty Hawk'']]. After he completed Naval Flight Officer training, reconnaissance training, & [[RA-5C Vigilante]] Replacement Air Group training, he served with [[RVAH-7]] at [[Naval Air Station Albany]], Georgia, until deploying to Southeast Asia aboard the aircraft carrier {{USS|Kitty Hawk|CV-63|6}} from February 1972 until he was shot down by enemy forces while on a reconnaissance mission over [[North Vietnam]] and was taken as a Prisoner of War on May 7, 1972. He was held as a [[prisoner of war]] for 11 months. Kernan was repatriated in 1973 and continued on active duty with the Navy until December 1974. Kernan received the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (U.S.)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], two [[Purple Heart]]s and the [[Navy Commendation Medal]].{{cite web|url=http://veterantributes.org/TributeDetail.php?recordID=1059|title=Veteran Tributes|website=veterantributes.org}} After completing his Naval service, Kernan worked for Procter and Gamble in Cincinnati in 1975. He then returned to South Bend, where he worked for both the Schwarz Paper Company and the MacWilliams Corporation. He was South Bend's city controller from 1980 to 1984. https://www.in.gov/governorhistory/2332.htm ==Political career== [[File:Reagan Contact Sheet C45772 (cropped2).jpg|thumb|right|Kernan greeting [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1988]] Joe Kernan was elected mayor of South Bend in 1987, 1991 and again in 1995, when he won with more than 82% of the vote.https://www.in.gov/governorhistory/2332.htm In 1996, Kernan was elected as Indiana's Lieutenant Governor, and then re-elected in 2000. As Lieutenant Governor, Kernan served as the President of the Indiana Senate, the Director of the Indiana Department of Commerce, and as the Commissioner of [[Agriculture]]. Originally, Kernan declined to seek the governorship during the 2004 election, but decided to do so upon assuming the governorship after the death of [[Frank O'Bannon]]. He was defeated by [[Mitch Daniels]] for a full four-year term in [[Indiana gubernatorial election, 2004|2004]]. ==Post-political career== Kernan returned to private life in January 2005 and became president of the [[South Bend Silver Hawks]] baseball club. In July 2007, Kernan and Indiana Chief Justice [[Randall Shepard]] were appointed by Daniels to co-chair the Indiana Commission on Local Government Reform.{{cite web |url=http://indianalocalgovreform.iu.edu/welcome/chairswelcome.html |title= Indiana Commission on Local Government Reform|accessdate=2009-03-15 |publisher= [[Indiana University School of Public and Environmental Affairs]]}} ==Personal life== In 1974 he married his wife, [[Maggie Kernan|Maggie]]. They have a home in South Bend, where Maggie works as a marketing specialist for 1st Source Bank. A Purdue University graduate who is active in community service, Maggie has been mentoring a child through a South Bend Community Schools program since 1994.https://www.in.gov/governorhistory/2332.htm ==See also== {{Portal|Indiana}} *[[List of Governors of Indiana]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{C-SPAN|josephkernan}} {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{Succession box|title=[[Lieutenant Governor of Indiana]] |before=Frank O'Bannon|after=[[Kathy Davis]] |years=January 13, 1997 – September 13, 2003}} {{Succession box|title=[[List of Governors of Indiana|Governor of Indiana]] |before=[[Frank O'Bannon]]|after=[[Mitch Daniels]] |years=September 13, 2003 – January 10, 2005}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Frank O'Bannon]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee for [[Governor of Indiana]]|years=[[Indiana gubernatorial election, 2004|2004]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[Jill Long Thompson]]}} {{S-end}} {{Governors of Indiana}} {{IndianaLtGovernors}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kernan, Joe}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Mayors of South Bend, Indiana]] [[Category:Governors of Indiana]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame alumni]] [[Category:United States Naval Aviators]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:Lieutenant Governors of Indiana]] [[Category:Indiana Democrats]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:American naval personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Vietnam War prisoners of war]] [[Category:Politicians from Chicago]] [[Category:People from Indiana in the Vietnam War]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Notre Dame Fighting Irish baseball players]] [[Category:Democratic Party state governors of the United States]] [[Category:Catholics from Illinois]]

{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = La Tomatina |type = cultural |image = La Tomatina 2014.jpg |imagesize = 300px |caption = La Tomatina in 2014 |official_name = La Tomatina |nickname = |observedby = [[Buñol]], [[Valencian Community|Valencia]], Spain |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = |week_ordinal = last |weekday = Wednesday |month = August |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = |frequency = annual |duration = 1 day }} '''''La Tomatina''''' ({{IPA-es|la tomaˈtina|va}}) is a [[festival]] that is held in the [[Valencian Community|Valencian]] town of [[Buñol]], in the East of Spain {{convert|30|km|mi|0}} from the Mediterranean, in which participants throw [[tomato]]es and get involved in a tomato fight purely for entertainment purposes. Since 1945 it has been held on the last Wednesday of August, during a week of festivities in Buñol.
==History== {{refimprove section|date=May 2017}} [[File:La Tomatina (25.08.2010) - Spain, Buñol 21.jpg|thumb|La Tomatina 25-08-2010]] It started the last Wednesday of August in 1945 when some young people spent the time in the town square to attend the Giants and Big-Heads figures parade. The young boys decided to take part in a parade with musicians, Giants and Big-Heads figures. The energy of jovialities caused one participant's big head to fall off. The participant flew into a fit of rage, began hitting everything in his path. There was a market stall of vegetable that fell victim to the fury of the crowd. People started to pelt each other with tomatoes until the local forces ended that fruit battle.
The following year, some young people engaged in a pre-planned quarrel and brought their own tomatoes from home. Although the police broke it up, this began the early tradition. In the following years, the young boys' example had unwittingly made history.
La Tomatina was banned in the early 50s, however this did not stop the participants who were arrested. But the people protested the prohibition and the festivity was again allowed with more participants and increased passions. The festivity was again cancelled till 1957 when, as a sign of protest, the tomato burial was held. It was a demonstration in which the residents carried a coffin with a huge tomato inside. The parade was accompanied by a music band which played funeral marches. The protest was successful. La Tomatina Festival was finally permitted and became an official festival.
As a result of the report of Javier Basilio, a broadcaster from the Spanish television program called ''Informe Semanal'', the festivity started to be known throughout the rest of Spain. Since then, the number of participants increased year after year as well as the excitement about La Tomatina Festival. In 2002, La Tomatina of Buñol was declared Festivity of International Tourist Interest by the Secretary Department of Tourism due to its success.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://latomatina.info/en/la-tomatina/|title=La Tomatina – Página oficial|last=Studio|first=Socarrat|website=latomatina.info|language=es|access-date=2017-08-20}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Two men preparing greasy pole for La Tomatina festival.jpg|right|thumb|Preparing the "palo jabón".]] [[File:Arrojando tomates desde un camión - La Tomatina 2010.jpg|thumb|Throwing tomatoes from a truck.]]
Usually the fight lasts for about two hours, after which the town square is covered with tomato debris.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rte.ie/lifestyle/travel/features/2009/0626/141194-latomatina/ | title=La Tomatina | publisher=RTE | author=Mullins, Deirdre}}</ref> Fire trucks then hose down the streets and participants often use hoses that locals provide to remove the tomatoes from their bodies. Some participants go to the “[[Los Peñones]]” pool to wash. The [[citric acid]] in the tomatoes leads to the washed surfaces in the town becoming very clean.<ref name="losangeles">{{cite web | url=http://www.latimes.com/food/dailydish/la-dd-tomatina-food-fight-spain-20000-people-130-tons-tomatoes-20130828-story.html | title=La Tomatina festival: 20,000 people, 130 tons of tomatoes, 1 big mess | publisher=''The Los Angeles Times'' | date=August 28, 2013 | author=Harris, Jenn}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thetasteofspain.com/spanish-fiestas/la-tomatina/ | title=La Tomatina | publisher=The Taste of Spain|accessdate=August 24, 2017}}</ref>
Since 2013 participation in the event has been restricted to the holders of paid tickets. In 2015, it was estimated that almost {{gaps|145|000}} kg of tomatoes were thrown.<ref name="losangeles"/>
==Rules of the festival==
The city council follows a short list of instructions for the safety of the participants and the festival:<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rules of Tomatina Festival|url=http://latomatina.info/en/la-tomatina/#reglas|publisher=Tomatina}}</ref>
# Do not throw bottles or hard objects # Do not tear or throw t-shirts # Squash tomatoes before throwing them to avoid hurting others # Keep a safe distance from trucks # Stop throwing tomatoes after the second starter pistol shot # Follow the directions of security staff
==In other countries== La Tomatina Buñol has inspired similar celebrations in other parts of the world:
* Since 1982, the town of [[Twin Lakes, Lake County, Colorado]] has held a tomato fight called the "[[Colorado Texas Tomato War]]," in which [[Texas|Texans]] and [[Colorado|Coloradans]] square off. The Coloradans also attempt to overtake the Texans' straw [[Alamo Mission in San Antonio|Alamo]] effigy, generally succeeding. * Since 2004 the Colombian town of [[Sutamarchán]] holds a similar event on 15 June when a surplus of tomatoes is harvested.<ref name="Galván2014">{{cite book|last=Galván|first=Javier A.|title=They Do What? A Cultural Encyclopedia of Extraordinary and Exotic Customs from around the World: A Cultural Encyclopedia of Extraordinary and Exotic Customs from around the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e2RyBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA309|date=June 19, 2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-61069-342-4|pages=309–}}</ref> * In Costa Rica the town of San José de Trojas ([[Valverde Vega Canton]]) celebrates a Tomatina during the local Tomato Fair.<ref name="odd">{{cite web | url=http://oddculture.com/la-tomatina-tomato-festival-inspires-tomato-battle-in-usa/ | title=La Tomatina Tomato Festival Inspires Tomato Battle In USA | publisher=Odd Culture}}</ref> * In the town of [[Dongguan]] in southern [[Guangdong]] province in China, a tomato fight is held on October 19, during which they use up to 15 tons of tomatoes.<ref name="odd"/> * The City of [[Reno, Nevada]] in the United States also has an annual hour-long tomato fight that started in 2009. The event seems to take place on the last Sunday of August and is organized by the [[American Cancer Society]]. Organizers named the festival La Tomatina, and give full credit for the idea to the Spanish festival.<ref name="Galván2014"/> * In the Indian state of [[Karnataka]], the [[Karnataka Government]] banned the hosting of such a Tomatina event in [[Bangalore]] and [[Mysore]], after private organizers tried to organize one. Chief Minister [[D.V. Sadananda Gowda]] is quoted as saying: "In the name of 'La Tomatina' festival, permission should not be granted to waste tomatoes". A similar event planned in [[Delhi]] was cancelled after it received negative response from the public.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bangalore's Tomatina festival cancelled|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cities/bangalore-s-tomatina-festival-cancelled-134173|publisher=[[NDTV 24x7]] |accessdate=17 September 2011}}</ref> * [[Milwaukee's East Side]] Association holds an annual Tomato Romp during September in coordination with a [[Bloody Mary drink]] contest. Held since at least 2009 it is limited to 250 people in a caged-in area.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theeastside.org/happenings/tomato-romp | title=Tomato Romp | publisher=The East Side}}</ref> * [[Funtasia Island]], [[Patna]] hosted a similar ''La tomatina [[Holi]]'' event on March 26, 2013 at [[Funtasia Water Park]] in [[Patna]], [[India]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130327/jsp/bihar/story_16716909.jsp#.Ujs1WoGDk9s|title=Splash of La Tomatina adds to park revelry - Funmakers get drenched in tomatoes instead of gulal ahead of festival|publisher=Calcutta Telegraph}}</ref>
==In popular culture== * The festival was re-created for the song "[[Ik Junoon (Paint it red)|Ik Junoon (Paint It Red)]]" from the 2011 [[Bollywood]] film ''[[Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Abhay-Deol-goes-topless/Article1-703287.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130125091310/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Abhay-Deol-goes-topless/Article1-703287.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-25 |title=Abhay Deol goes topless! |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=2011-05-31 |accessdate=2011-06-29 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/features/type/view/id/1949/ |title=Check out: Hrithik, Katrina, Farhan & Abhay shooting for Tomatina fest in Spain |publisher=Bollywoodhungama.com |date=2011-03-19 |accessdate=2015-08-25}}</ref> * The opening scene of the film ''[[We Need to Talk About Kevin (film)|We Need to Talk About Kevin]]'' depicts the character Eva attending La Tomatina. * The Movie ''[[Spanish Masala]]'' has a scene showing the La Tomatina festival. * The 2014 British musical film ''[[Walking on Sunshine (film)|Walking on Sunshine]]'' features a tomato fight in an [[Apulia]]n village. It was shot in [[Nardò]], Italy.<ref name="FT">[https://www.ft.com/content/c1341406-f899-11e3-815f-00144feabdc0 On location: ‘Walking on Sunshine’], [[Joanne O’Connor]], 27 June 2014, [[Financial Times]]</ref>
==See also== *[[Battle of the Oranges]], similar traditional festival in Ivrea, Italy *[[Fiestas of International Tourist Interest of Spain]] *[[Running of the Bulls]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
